Award.AwardTitle: TTP: Small: Collaborative: Defending Against Website Fingerprinting in Tor

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The more people use the Internet, the more they risk sharing information they don't want other people to know. Tor is a technology that every day helps millions of people protect their privacy online. Tor users -- ranging from ordinary citizens to companies with valuable intellectual property -- gain protection for the content of their online messages and activities, as well as whom they interact with and when. For the most part, Tor is very secure. However, it has a known vulnerability to an attack called website fingerprinting. An attacker, such as someone eavesdropping on a wireless connection, can analyze recognizable patterns in data that websites send to visitors, potentially determining which websites a user visits. Studies have shown that, in some situations, this attack can be successful up to 90% of the time. Developers of Tor and a team of researchers will collaborate to build and deploy new defenses against website fingerprinting, which substantially lower attack accuracy without degrading user experience or increasing the costs of running the system. By widely deploying such a defense, Tor's security is greatly improved. This also provides an experimental platform and data that other researchers can use for their own experiments, helping to further strengthen Tor.

Previous approaches to defending against website fingerprinting increased latency, so that web pages load 2 to 4 times slower than normal. To design an effective defense that doesn't unacceptably slow browsing or increase bandwidth overhead, this project builds on a technique called Adaptive Padding, which has shown promising results in preliminary work. Adaptive Padding works by noticing distinctive gaps in data packets flowing over the network between a website and Tor user and filling these gaps with extra packets to obfuscate the website's fingerprint. The research team first developed a platform for evaluating Adaptive Padding and other defenses in Tor, allowing security experiments in the live Tor network without full deployment or endangering user privacy. Leveraging this platform, the team performs extensive experiments on website fingerprinting defenses and attacks, leading towards deployment. The project focuses on defenses that can be practically deployed and significantly improve user security. Since defenses meeting these requirements have been understudied to date, this project enhances knowledge in this area. Finally, the findings of the project are fully transitioned to Tor to make Internet browsing safer and more secure.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tor system for online privacy is vulnerable to an attack called website fingprinting, which can reveal which websites a user is visiting even though the Tor connections are encrypted. This project developed the framework for a defense against website fingerprinting and deployed it the Tor system. The RIT team developed additional components for this framework to enable researchers and developers to test different ideas for effective defenses. Further, they extensively investigated both ways in which an attacker could attempt to undermine the defense and ways to mitigate those additional attacks. These studies used state-of-the-art advances in deep learning, i.e. artificial intelligence based on powerful neural networks. The project found that previously proposed defenses can be undermined by these deep learning techniques, but also discovered novel ways to confuse the attacker. Through these contributions, researchers and developers have key building blocks needed for protecting the privacy of Tor users.


The RIT team produced two github repositories with a large data set and the code showing how two attacks work, as well as a github repository for their contributions to the Tor defense. In addition to disseminating their discoveries by publishing numerous papers in the top venues in cybersecurity, the project team gave over 20 presentations about this work in universities, conferences, and events for cybersecurity professionals. The project also helped to train several graduate and undergraduate students in research covering cybersecurity, privacy, and artificial intelligence. Furthermore, the project helped lead to new coursework and capstone projects, exposing another 30 or more students to the research.


Last Modified: 11/27/2019
Modified by: Matthew Wright

This project developed the framework for a defense against website fingerprinting and deployed it the Tor system. The RIT team developed additional components for this framework to enable researchers and developers to test different ideas for effective defenses. Further, they extensively investigated both ways in which an attacker could attempt to undermine the defense and ways to mitigate those additional attacks. These studies used state-of-the-art advances in deep learning, i.e. artificial intelligence based on powerful neural networks. The project found that previously proposed defenses can be undermined by these deep learning techniques, but also discovered novel ways to confuse the attacker. Through these contributions, researchers and developers have key building blocks needed for protecting the privacy of Tor users. The RIT team produced two github repositories with a large data set and the code showing how two attacks work, as well as a github repository for their contributions to the Tor defense. In addition to disseminating their discoveries by publishing numerous papers in the top venues in cybersecurity, the project team gave over 20 presentations about this work in universities, conferences, and events for cybersecurity professionals. The project also helped to train several graduate and undergraduate students in research covering cybersecurity, privacy, and artificial intelligence. Furthermore, the project helped lead to new coursework and capstone projects, exposing another 30 or more students to the research. Last Modified: 11/27/2019 Submitted by: Matthew Wright
